awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Life Out of Water - Possibility of Evolution in Non-Aqueous Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Life on Earth is thought to have emerged in water phase. It is not known whether the chemical processes of Life can only occur in a polar liquid like water, or also in non-polar, oily liquids. This project will examine chemistry in non-polar phases to ask whether certain aspects of genetic coding and mutation with selection can take place in the absence of water. The project will provide training in organic chemistry, biochemistry and physical chemistry to many students. 

Water is assumed to be a necessity for life. This project will study a counter-factual proposition that certain aspects of extant life on Earth, including genetic coding and mutation with selection, can be reimplemented in the absence of water. To that end, the solubility, folding, assembly and co-assembly of non-polar homologs of canonical nucleic acid monomers and oligomers, wherein the phosphodiester linkage is substituted with a non-polar linkage will be characterized. Dynamic-covalent reactions as alternatives to base-pairing in organic media will be explored and in vitro selection will be performed in oil phase and in oil-water alternating regimes. The project will involve undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers, with student exchange between laboratories, and facilitate mentoring and outreach through SAGANet and K-12 workshops.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
The origin of life is one of the biggest questions in science. Investigating the first evolutionary steps in the transition of life on Earth from non-life is extraordinarily challenging since it happened billions of years ago. And the environmental conditions are uncertain, at best. So instead, we investigated the potential for the origin of life, in general, examining sufficient conditions for life-like processes to emerge. 

We developed a new platform for studying the origin of life that can be used under a wide variety of environmental conditions. We observed rapid evolutionary responses that bear the hallmarks of adaptation. The responses were environment specific, with entirely different responses to selection depending on whether the environment was simple or complex. In simple environments, we observe the evolution of a few competitively superior individual types that have one of a relatively few beneficial motifs. The total diversity of individuals is relatively small. In complex environments, there is a tremendous diversity of individuals that evolve much greater complexity. Rather than the emergence of a few selectively beneficial individuals as observed in the simple environment, there are no dominant individual types, and variation in size is the predominant evolutionary response to selection. 

Our study demonstrates that the evolutionary principles observed in existing complex biological systems also hold for non-living systems. That differences in environmental complexity profoundly affect the evolution of "non-living" systems. And that laboratory investigations of the origins of life can provide insights into the scope for the origins of life generally.


Last Modified: 05/05/2023
Modified by: Michael Travisano
